message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of herpes vesicles on the vulvar region makes vaginal delivery contraindicated due to the risk of neonatal herpes infection. Oral acyclovir therapy should be initiated to suppress the outbreak and decrease the risk of transmission. Cesarean delivery should be performed to avoid exposure of the neonate to active lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of active genital herpes at the time of delivery puts the baby at risk for neonatal herpes, which can be life-threatening. Therefore, the most appropriate next step is to recommend oral acyclovir therapy and delivery via cesarean section. Topical acyclovir may not be effective enough, and tocolytic therapy is not indicated as the patient is already in active labor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of active genital herpes at the time of delivery increases the risk of transmission to the newborn, which can lead to severe neonatal infection. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommends that women with active genital herpes lesions at the time of delivery should undergo cesarean delivery. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is oral acyclovir therapy and cesarean delivery. Topical acyclovir is not effective in preventing transmission to the newborn. Tocolytic therapy is not indicated as it would delay delivery and increase the risk of neonatal infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of vesicles on an erythematous base over the vulvar region suggests a herpes simplex virus infection. As such, the baby may be at risk of acquiring the infection during vaginal delivery. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is oral acyclovir therapy and cesarean delivery. Tocolytic therapy is not indicated since the patient is already in active labor. Topical acyclovir is not effective for the treatment of genital herpes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of vesicles suggests active herpes simplex virus infection, which poses a risk to the neonate during labor and delivery. The most appropriate next step would be to treat with oral acyclovir therapy and perform a cesarean delivery to prevent transmission of the virus to the baby. Tocolytic therapy is not indicated, and topical acyclovir may not be effective enough.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of active genital herpes during delivery is an indication for cesarean delivery to prevent transmission of the virus to the neonate. Tocolytics are not indicated in this case. Topical acyclovir may not be sufficient in treating an active outbreak during labor, and oral acyclovir therapy is indicated, but only in combination with cesarean delivery to reduce the risk of neonatal transmission.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has active genital herpes at the time of delivery, so the most appropriate method of delivery is a cesarean section to prevent transmission of the virus to the infant. Oral acyclovir therapy can be used to treat the herpes, but it does not change the method of delivery. Topical acyclovir is not effective in treating active genital herpes. Tocolytic therapy is not indicated in this situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of genital herpes and the presence of grouped vesicles over the vulvar region suggest an active outbreak of herpes simplex virus (HSV). In a pregnant woman, the risk of transmission to the newborn is high if vaginal delivery is chosen. Therefore, oral acyclovir therapy and cesarean delivery are the most appropriate next steps in management. Tocolytic therapy is not necessary, and topical acyclovir may not be effective in treating this systemic infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of vesicles over the vulvar region suggests active genital herpes at the time of delivery, which increases the risk of neonatal herpes infection. Therefore, cesarean delivery is advised to prevent neonatal herpes. Oral acyclovir therapy is also recommended to reduce maternal symptoms and decrease the risk of neonatal herpes. Tocolytic therapy is not indicated in this case. Topical acyclovir may help reduce symptoms but is not effective in preventing neonatal herpes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of active herpes lesions during delivery is a contraindication to vaginal delivery due to the risk of transmission to the newborn. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is oral acyclovir therapy and cesarean delivery. Topical acyclovir may not be effective enough, and tocolytic therapy is not indicated in this case.
